We provide axioms that guarantee a category is equivalent to that of continuous linear functions between Hilbert spaces. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of hosts, including humans. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been elusive, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a less reduced cnidarian species. Our results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite.

The study of the molecular mechanisms of viral antagonism is of great interest for the development of new antiviral strategies. In this work, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our results provide a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of IFN and may help to develop new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 is not completely understood. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. These results have important implications for the stability of global grain trade and international grain prices, especially for the 800 million people living in extreme poverty. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a fundamental question in ecology. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap at a species level, and that this approach can be used to show that the degree of diet overlap is strongly correlated with the degree of diet similarity. We also show that the degree of diet overlap is strongly correlated with the degree of diet similarity, and that this relationship holds across trophic guilds. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large herbivore assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off or closed, and that the longer the crisis lasts, the more likely businesses are to remain open. However, many businesses are financially fragile, and many more anticipate problems accessing the government’s loan program.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible signs of the environmental impact of human activities. However, the magnitude of the problem is still debated. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly because of the selective removal of small particles by food webs and ballasting processes. This study is of fundamental importance to understand the nature and the significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga, which is consistent with the age of the solar system. However, a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We show that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. We also show that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. These results provide a new constraint for the origin of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This will challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we show that the ability to provide energy to offspring correlates with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the energy available to the mother rather than an increase in the number of litters. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of reproduction and the evolution of domestication.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the inflammatory protease caspase-1 cleaves the C terminus of α-syn, which is then prone to aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. Finally, we show that VX-765 is able to preserve tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra of the mouse model. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the interface between the circulatory system and the tissues of the body. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and tissues. This paper provides a description of the structure and function of the endothelial network, which is the communication system between endothelial cells. The network is designed to be both local and global in its communication, and to be robust and fast in its response to stimuli.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on the pandemic and public behavior. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are useful for tracking the pandemic, for epidemiological modeling, and for research and decision-making. The data are also useful for studying the impact of public health interventions, such as lockdowns and mask mandates.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter is a prerequisite for the allosteric communication. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This study provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in K+ channels. It also provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the closed state and the C-type inactivation in K+ channels. This study also provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the closed state and the C-type inactivation in K+ channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health of the host. However, the natural products that are produced by the gut microbiome are largely unknown. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi in the gut microbiome produce a diverse range of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and antimicrobials of plant origin. This study provides a foundation for the discovery of natural products from the gut microbiome and the development of new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We provide evidence that high-anxious individuals are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and that this is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, enhances brain energy metabolism and prevents the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical devices with complex and programmable responses is of great importance for various applications. However, the design space is limited by the material properties and structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases that can seamlessly collaborate to produce arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures are effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be extended to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of programmable mechanical devices.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin gene is expressed in two forms, alpha-globin and beta-globin, which are expressed in different tissues and at different times in development. We show that the protein-binding protein IGF2BP1 is expressed in the developing human fetus and is down-regulated in the adult. We show that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the expression of fetal hemoglobin in the adult.

Cancer is a disease of the metabolic system, and cancer cells are characterized by high rates of glycolysis and low rates of oxidative phosphorylation. This study shows that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway are resistant to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In contrast, SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for ferroptosis induction in cancer cells with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. Thus, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows promise as a therapeutic strategy for cancer. This study provides a mechanism for understanding the metabolic basis of cancer resistance to ferroptosis, and it may lead to the development of new therapies for cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure, the leading cause of hospitalization and death in the United States. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers, which are associated with an increased risk of heart failure. We show that these drugs promote vascular remodeling, a pathological hallmark of hypertension, through a mechanism involving the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Ca2+ sensor STIM1 and the plasma membrane ORAI channels. Our findings provide a rationale for the increased risk of heart failure associated with the use of calcium channel blockers and may lead to the development of new therapies for hypertension. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations associated with early-seral forests, but not older forests. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations, which accelerated due to a combination of factors, including the loss of older forests to fire and clearcutting elsewhere. Our results highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is a major challenge, and computational approaches are essential tools to this end. In this study, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The results of this study provide a valuable resource for the development of new antibiotics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is based on a simple idea: use dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connect all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in the future.

The evolution of the African Rift System and the formation of Lake Malawi are linked to the development of a unique cichlid fish fauna. The lake is a critical ecosystem, providing habitat for a large number of endemic species, and is a key site for the study of evolution and speciation. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of hydroclimate variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The record shows that the lake has been dry for 24 times over the past 1.3 My, and that the evolution of the cichlid fish fauna has been linked to the development of a wetter climate.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become ubiquitous in the past 50 y. However, the biological effects of such technology use on sleep and health are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known event in the Earth sciences, but its cause is still debated. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses is that one or more bolide impacts triggered the cooling. We show that the osmium isotope composition of the Younger Dryas ejecta is consistent with the terrestrial origin of the element.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the periphery and the central nervous system.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles and their plant-feeding habits is linked to the evolution of enzymes that digest plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for other protein molecules, including vaccines and other therapeutics. Our work provides a new avenue for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense interest in the social sciences. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the APOE genotype. APOE is a protein that is produced by astrocytes, a type of glial cell that is highly phagocytic. We found that APOE isoform regulates the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which are the cellular units of cognition. APOE2 enhances the rate of phagocytosis of synapses by astrocytes, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in astrocytes, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers show reduced decreases in brain DA responses to methylphenidate, which is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of marijuana on the brain and for the development of effective treatment strategies for marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for language processing also predict the neural activity of human observers comprehending sentences. This finding provides computational evidence for a fundamental role of predictive processing in the brain’s language comprehension mechanisms.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful paradigm in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability is not intrinsic to DL, but rather a consequence of the current training algorithms. We prove that there are well-conditioned problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. This paper establishes a classification theory of stability, which is a necessary condition for the existence of algorithms that compute stable NNs. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. We believe that this work will help to establish the role of stability in deep learning and scientific computing in general.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the limits of science. The scientific community is currently debating the role of social media in the spread of misinformation. In this context, it is important to critically assess the role of science in the spread of misinformation. This paper shows that the scientific community is not only guilty of spreading misinformation itself, but also of falling prey to the same cognitive biases that it studies.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which causes the disease in the peripheral nervous system, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the disease in the brain and spinal cord. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are remarkably similar, and that they have retained many of the same functions. This suggests that they have been able to adapt to their respective niches, and that they are still able to cause disease.

The evolution of entanglement is a fundamental question in quantum mechanics. It is also a key ingredient in the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is a direct consequence of integrability and leads to a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The development of a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, is a global priority. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 recoded with synonymous suboptimal codons, resulting in a 283-amino acid deletion. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. In hamsters, the vaccine candidate is more than 100-fold less virulent than the wild-type virus. In addition, the vaccine candidate generates high levels of neutralizing antibodies and protection against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. These results support the potential of COVI-VAC as a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2. The development of this vaccine candidate is a testament to the power of science to respond to a global crisis. We hope that the development of COVI-VAC will contribute to the global fight against COVID-19. (Show more)

The Black Death, caused by Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating pandemics in history. The disease led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We present a mathematical model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which were common in Europe during the Second Pandemic. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague and its impact on human societies.

The evolution of brain size has been a major focus of comparative neuroethology. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity has been less studied. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only way to measure the evolution of cognitive capacity. We use neuron numbers to measure the evolution of brain information-processing capacity and show that the evolution of brain size is not the only way to measure the evolution of cognitive capacity.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is controlled by a number of factors. One of these factors is TRAP1, which is found predominantly in mitochondria. We have shown that TRAP1 is required for the survival of cells in the cell cycle.

Actin filaments are the building blocks of the cytoskeleton, which is the network of filaments that provides the physical support to cells. Actin filaments are also the main substrate for the ADF/cofilin family of proteins, which are the main regulators of actin filament disassembly. We show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments, and that this process is enhanced by mechanical stress. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages. This study shows that the ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its relationship to the development of eating disorders. They also have implications for understanding the role of food cues in the development of overeating and weight gain. Finally, they have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of addiction.

Madagascar is a unique island, both in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we show that the island was settled by multiple waves of people, with a recent contribution of people from Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. The settlement history is consistent with the island being settled from both Africa and Asia, rather than from a single source. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island shows that the settlement was not homogeneous, and that the genetic structure is also not homogeneous. These results have important implications for the settlement history of Madagascar and for the distribution of genetic diversity across the planet.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a new way of understanding the role of social media in our lives, and it suggests that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not in the same room. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are modified in a variety of ways that can have important effects on protein synthesis. In this work, we show that the most common mRNA modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), can have a modest effect on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the ribosome–mRNA complex can increase the rate of translation of some codons, and that the presence of Ψ in coding regions can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings suggest that mRNA modifications can have subtle effects on translation, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in the course of decoding mRNAs. Our results have implications for understanding the effects of mRNA modifications on translation and for the design of therapeutic drugs that target protein synthesis. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more favorable lifestyle behaviors, and stronger social relationships. These associations are independent of factors such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and prosperity. The feeling that life is worthwhile may be a key factor in the maintenance of health and well-being across the life course.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in biology. We show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common disease worldwide, and rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the virus replicates more efficiently at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies to reduce the incidence of the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a leading cause of infections in the hospital and in the community. It is a master of adaptation, and can cause disease in a variety of host environments, including the human body, the environment, and the food chain. This study shows that P. aeruginosa can sense the mechanical activity of its pili, and that this sensing is required for the development of a biofilm, a major cause of infections. This study provides a new perspective on the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the human population, and the emergence of new variants has complicated the response. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife is a concern, as it could lead to the emergence of new variants that are better adapted to transmission between animals and humans. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, and the identification of multiple lineages in both deer and humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic, and highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a global problem that is affecting the lives of millions of people. This paper examines the causes of the problem, the impacts of the dams, and the solutions that are needed.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation and progression of AD is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type in the brain, are also vulnerable to Aβ toxicity. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons produce a variety of potent immune factors, which correlate with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization. Moreover, we identify an inflammatory profile unique to Aβ-burdened neurons, since neighboring glial cells did not express similar molecules. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. (PsycINFO Database Record

The history of the chicken is one of the most fascinating in the history of agriculture. It is also one of the most complex, as it is the result of a long process of acclimatization of a wild species to the conditions of human husbandry. The results of our study show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in the world is found in the Hellenistic city of Maresha, Israel. This finding has important implications for the history of the chicken and for the process of its acclimatization to human husbandry.

The folding of a protein is a key process in biology, and the study of its mechanism is a major goal of biophysics. This study adds a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The study also provides a new method for studying protein folding.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing these caps, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, prefers to remove capped RNAs as substrates over their capped counterparts, and that the enzyme recognizes capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. These findings have implications for the regulation of gene expression during stress.

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with a high mortality rate. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of immune dysfunction is the depletion of T lymphocytes. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is able to restore the immune system in sepsis. This study provides a new therapeutic strategy for sepsis patients.

The biomass of all living organisms is a fundamental quantity for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. They also provide a reference for future studies on the biomass of other systems.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and physics, where a system evolves in time in a way that the rate of change is proportional to the current system activity. SOC systems are critical in the sense that the system activity is not sensitive to small changes in the external conditions, but rather to large changes. SOC systems are also scale invariant, meaning that the system properties are the same at all length scales. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. This work provides a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic, optical, and mechanical properties of diamond. It also provides a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic, optical, and mechanical properties of diamond.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the pharmaceutical industry and the scientific community. This study provides a structural and functional insight into the mode of action of a unique peptide, which is a member of the family of cysteine-rich peptides.

The female reproductive tract (FRT) is a critical site for sperm maturation and fertilization. However, the extent to which the FRT contributes to sperm function is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the FRT. We also show that the proteome of sperm in the FRT is enriched with proteins that are associated with the FRT and are likely to be female-derived. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, where it promotes blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster binding, providing a mechanism for the pathophysiology of VWD. The mechanism is similar to that of other proteins, but the effects on VWF are much greater than for other proteins, because of the large size of VWF.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and we show that viruses are strongly associated with many diseases. This resource will enable the study of the role of viruses in human health and disease, and will be useful for the study of viruses in other ecosystems.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system, but is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. The HSRL observations over Beijing, China, highlight the scientific potential of the HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. We expect that this technique will be a significant contribution to the ACI investigations. The origin of life is one of the most important scientific questions of our time. The temperature of the early Earth has been a key factor in the debate over the origin of life. We show that the temperature of the surface of the early Earth decreased over time, from 65–80 °C in the Archean to the present 15 °C.

Ion channels are the gates of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to regulate ion flow. Ion channels commonly possess two pore gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel’s C-type inactivation is state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels. It also provides a new target for drug development.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 216 million cases and 445,000 deaths in 2017. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a number of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. Here, we show that the malaria parasite uses a number of physical mechanisms to prime the RBC surface, reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum devices, and thermal management. However, its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities, and its mechanical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that its bandgap can be tuned reversibly by strain. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. This work provides a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic, optical, and mechanical properties of diamond. It also provides a platform for exploring the relationship between the electronic, optical, and mechanical properties of diamond.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans and animals. In this study, we show that exposure to dry air, which is common in many temperate regions, impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. These findings have important implications for understanding the impact of climate change on influenza epidemics and for developing strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza in the future. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is not supported by neurophysiological data. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a neural implementation of a merge operation, which applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be important for understanding the brain’s processing of other complex sequences, such as speech and music.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is involved in a wide range of biological processes. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the pathway. This study provides a deeper understanding of the regulation of redundant genes and may be useful in the development of new therapies.

Obesity is a major public health problem, and the mechanisms that govern overeating are not well understood. Here we report a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces rapid vigorous eating in sated mice. This effect is blocked by dopamine receptor antagonists, and dopamine lesions or lesions of the ventral tegmental area or substantia nigra do not disrupt the effect. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is dependent on a circuit that includes the lateral hypothalamus, ventral tegmentum, and locus coeruleus. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

Symbiotic associations between plants and bacteria are fundamental to the functioning of the biosphere, but they are also a source of agricultural inefficiency. One of the most important limitations of these associations is the inability of the plant to control the behavior of the symbiont. Here, we demonstrate a method for controlling the behavior of a nitrogen-fixing symbiont in a plant.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that combined remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals hear the world around them, and hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the wispy, wheel-shaped orb web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave, such as those emitted by approaching prey or predators. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The development of vaccines is a global effort, and many countries are still in need of a safe and effective vaccine. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is well-suited for large-scale production and elicits a strong immune response. This protein can be used to generate a virus-like particle, which can be used as a vaccine. This protein can also be used to generate a vaccine in combination with other antigens.

We show that the zebrafish homolog of the ALK oncogene, DrALKals, is involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of neural crest origin. We also show that the ALKALs are able to activate the ALK/LTK family of receptors in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a link between ALK/LTK family receptors and neural crest development and opens up the possibility to study the role of ALK/LTK in human development and cancer.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been a constant threat to humanity for millennia. We present the first ancient Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical time in the development of the pathogen. Our results show that the Y. pestis lineage that gave rise to the plague pandemic in the 14th century CE persisted for thousands of years, and that the emergence of the flea-adapted form of the pathogen occurred much earlier than previously thought. These data provide a unique window into the formative years of plague, and will be of great interest to evolutionary and medical researchers.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM was also associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia. These findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 presidential election.

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a key question in the context of climate change. We show that soil management practices that reduce soil disturbance and incorporate legumes and manure into annual cropping systems can increase SOC storage in the top 15 cm of soil. These practices also increase the proportion of SOC in the more stable mineral-associated fraction. However, the effects of these practices on soil microbial biomass and community structure were mixed. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC and the importance of considering the soil microbial community in the design of climate-smart agricultural systems. This study provides a case study of the effects of soil health management practices on soil carbon in the context of a global meta-analysis.

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses was validated by the fact that the top 12 were known zoonotic viruses. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. We show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a mechanism for the production of this pigment in plants, which is likely to be of general interest to the study of plant–animal interactions.

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages is poorly understood. We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 7th centuries AD. We show that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that the genetic ancestry of women is very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. We also show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Middle Ages and the processes that shaped the modern European genetic landscape.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses are important for understanding the origins of bat coronaviruses and their potential to cause human infections. Here, we report that the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of two bat coronaviruses, HKU4 and HKU5, are different from that of the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus. These results suggest that the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses have the potential to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmission. This study also provides a foundation for understanding the origins of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus and other bat coronaviruses. It also provides a reference for the development of vaccines and drugs against future bat coronavirus threats to human health. (Show more)

This study demonstrates the use of a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify a diverse range of pathogens in a resource-scarce setting. The study also highlights the importance of pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, but where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. The study provides a blueprint for the use of mNGS in resource-scarce settings, and the results will inform the development of a national mNGS platform in Cambodia.

The human genome is synthesized in a series of short fragments, called Okazaki fragments, which are joined together by DNA ligase. The synthesis of these fragments is catalyzed by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). The process is highly processive and requires the binding of the PCNA sliding clamp to the pol δ holoenzyme. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the pol δ holoenzyme is highly processive and maintains a loose association with the PCNA clamp while replicating DNA. This behavior has profound implications on the synthesis of Okazaki fragments in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from the PCNA clamp on stalling at a DNA lesion. These results provide a unique perspective on the role of the PCNA clamp in the regulation of DNA synthesis. They also provide a foundation for the development of new strategies for the treatment of cancer.

The origin of life is one of the most important problems in biology. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA. In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA, and, in the absence of proteins, can synthesize a variety of functional RNA molecules. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, these results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. We have found that the patients with severe COVID-19 have high levels of interleukin 6, which may be the cause of the inflammatory storm. We have found that tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, can reduce the levels of interleukin 6 and improve the clinical condition of patients with severe COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal, and the maintenance of sufficient but nontoxic pools of copper is a fundamental challenge for fungi. We report the discovery of a fungal natural product, xanthocillin, that binds copper and has antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study provides insight into the evolution of the role of natural products in the maintenance of essential metals and the control of microbial interactions. (Show more)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary environment is a unique discovery. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment on another planet is a significant discovery.

Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals, but the geographic distribution of frost events and their impact on the evolution of species are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is linked to the leaf-out strategies of trees, and that the resistance strategies of trees are linked to the rate of change in frost events. Our findings can help to predict the impact of frost on forest ecosystems and to develop strategies for adaptation.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the role of Th17 cells in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease is not well understood. We show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells, and that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease pathogenesis. This study also provides a model for the study of the development of Th17 cells in inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is also driven by the actions of astrocytes. We report a method to rapidly convert human fibroblasts into astrocytes, which can be used to study the disease process and to screen for drugs to treat the disease. This method will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases in which astrocytes play a role.

This study provides a unique example of a pathogen using an antibacterial protein from its vector to enhance colonization. The study also provides a model for understanding the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the host microbiota.

Birds are a highly diverse group of animals, and the study of their evolution has been a major focus of paleontology for over a century. However, the study of the origins of the modern avian bauplan has been complicated by the limited known diversity of early branching members of the group. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, and the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia, that adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan.

We show that the stratospheric water vapor feedback is a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity of the climate system. This feedback is important because it is positive, meaning that it increases the radiative forcing of a given climate change. We show that the strength of this feedback is due to an increase in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are green. This study describes the molecular basis of green coloration in vertebrates, and shows that the color of the animal can be fine-tuned by physiological concentrations of a specific group of proteins.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. The development of breast cancer is associated with hypoxia, which is a major stress condition that can be used to induce the expression of genes associated with cancer stem cells. We show that hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. This study provides a mechanism for the induction of breast cancer stem cells in response to hypoxia. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer. (Show more)

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method for identifying the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbits, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. This refined age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, and will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Less)

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the presence of inflammation and immune responses in the intestinal mucosa. IBD is a complex disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unknown. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the pathogenesis of IBD. We generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also found that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the human receptor, ACE2, and the fusion peptide at 3.2 Å resolution. We show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results provide a structural basis for the increased transmissibility of the mutant virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.
