COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.6 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 82.1 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The study of the chemical properties of matter under pressure is of fundamental importance for the understanding of the physical properties of matter, and it is also of great interest for the development of new materials. We show that the chemical properties of matter change under pressure, and we provide a quantitative description of these changes.

We show that the effects of human ignitions and fire suppression on fire regimes are as important as changes in climate for driving future warming. This is important because of the large uncertainties in climate projections and the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle. We find that, although climate change has already warmed the planet, changes in human demography have suppressed global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, this effect is likely to reverse in the future, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts in the animal kingdom. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of the mutualism between the two organisms. This glycan is consumed by the symbiont only at night, when the animal is active, and is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which enhances the level of oxygen available to the symbionts. This glycan-driven regulation of the symbiont’s habitat may be a general mechanism for the control of the activities of symbionts in the animal kingdom.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the volume of text is growing exponentially. We need methods to identify latent patterns in text data. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe that this method will be useful to many researchers in the social sciences and beyond.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period of plague outbreaks is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium into Europe, after which the disease established itself in rodents. We show that this assumption is not supported by our analysis of climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague outbreaks. We find that the bacterium was repeatedly reintroduced into Europe from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the rodent reservoirs were not permanent, and that the disease was maintained by repeated introductions. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague pandemic. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine ecosystem, and their loss would have a significant impact on the global carbon cycle. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the asteroid wasting disease, which has led to the loss of at least 90% of the population of a species of asteroid on the Pacific coast of North America.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly aggressive cancer with a poor prognosis. The identification of AML stem cells is a major challenge, and there is an urgent need for new therapies. We show here that antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) are effective in AML xenograft models and are able to kill AML cells in vitro and in vivo. These antibodies are able to mediate antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and block IL-1 signaling. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results provide a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies as a treatment for AML. This study may lead to the development of new therapies for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased and heterogeneous way, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar was not a single event but rather a series of independent events. Finally, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. We show that the RNA and protein interact, and that the protein interferes with the RNA’s ability to repress two genes. We also show that the RNA and protein compete for the same translation initiation complex. This is an example of a complex regulatory system that is not well understood.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. We anticipate that our approach will be useful for other protein molecules, including vaccines and other therapeutics. Our work provides a new avenue for the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their assessments are critical for monitoring crop status and predicting crop yields. However, the vast majority of crop experts are not part of the formal agricultural system, and their assessments are not captured by official sources of information. We propose a method to convert the original categorical crop expert assessments into a continuous probabilistic variable, and show that this variable is robust to changes in the survey design and is valid across the nation. We demonstrate that this probabilistic variable can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” to monitor and manage agricultural production.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during the course of experience. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the order in which information is presented. We show that this mechanism can support the binding of linguistic features over time, and it can support the integration of information over time within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, and the results have been inconsistent. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a powerful tool for understanding the origin and evolution of life. However, the evolutionary history of the plastid genome is not only shaped by the history of the host cell, but also by the history of the parasite. Here, we show that the evolutionary history of the plastid genome is shaped by the evolutionary history of the host cell.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also highlight the importance of regional-scale studies, which are not possible with global models. We hope that our results will be useful to water managers and policy makers in SSA.

The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion, the “Trinity test,” has been a major event in the history of science. The discovery of a new quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the oldest known anthropogenic material, is a major event in the history of science and technology.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. It is powered by light, which is captured by chlorophyll, a molecule that is made in a highly productive biosynthetic pathway. This pathway is the most productive biological pathway on Earth, and it is the basis of the oxygen cycle on our planet.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in many neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is a complex process involving multiple cell types, and the role of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase 1 (ASK1) in neuroinflammation is not well understood. In this study, we found that ASK1 is required for neuroinflammation in the later stage of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), and ASK1 deficiency in microglia but not astrocytes ameliorated the later-stage neuroinflammation. ASK1 in microglia plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, which further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation and may lead to the development of new strategies for treating neurodegenerative diseases. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We show that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of forgetting in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. This work is a cross-national replication of a 2016 study that demonstrated the prevalence of negativity biases in human cognition and behavior. The current work extends this research in several ways. First, it examines the extent to which these biases are present in a sample of 17 countries, 6 continents, and 1,000 participants per country. Second, it examines the extent to which these biases vary across individuals, and finds that they do. Third, it examines the extent to which these biases vary across news content, and finds that they do. Fourth, it examines the extent to which these biases vary across news media, and finds that they do. Fifth, it examines the extent to which these biases vary across cultures, and finds that they do. Finally, it examines the extent to which these biases vary across news content and culture, and finds that they do. Taken together, these results help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative.

The store-operated Ca2+ (SO) sensor STIM1 and the SO channel ORAI1 are important regulators of cellular physiology, but their functions are not fully understood. Here, we report the identification of patients with Stormorken syndrome, and show that mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 result in constitutive activation of the SO channel, leading to the development of hematological and skeletal muscle abnormalities. Our findings provide insights into the molecular basis of SO channel dysregulation, and suggest new therapeutic strategies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous, and that the spreading of aggregates causes the death of vulnerable neurons. We also show that the spread of aggregates requires the fusion of lysosomes and the endocytic system, and that the release of aggregates requires the fusion of lysosomes and the endocytic system. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses and the potential of bats as a source of novel therapeutics. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used it to identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. We show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell cancers, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells that can be exploited to treat cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form characteristic intracellular inclusion bodies that are present in all forms of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the inclusion bodies in ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This metastable state is likely a consequence of the cellular environment in motor neurons, which are highly specialized for the transmission of nerve impulses. Our results suggest that the metastable state of these proteins may be a common feature of neurodegenerative diseases, and may be a target for therapeutic intervention. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. We believe that the results presented here will be of interest to a broad community of researchers in the fields of quantum optics, atom optics, and many-body physics. The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, a fossil plant from the Cretaceous, has led to a better understanding of the evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, but the evolution of the human parvovirus B19 (B19V) has been a source of controversy. Here we present the genomes of B19V from ancient human remains, which show that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time. We also show that the evolution of B19V is slower than previously thought, which has important implications for the study of the evolution of viruses in general.
We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and that this acceleration is consistent with climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that, for those with less education, pain prevalence has risen with age for each successive birth cohort, and that this pattern is likely to continue for tomorrow’s elderly. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. In this work, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of a key enzyme intermediate. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the case fatality rate is high. We show that remdesivir, a drug used for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in nonhuman primates. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection in humans. It also provides a rationale for the use of remdesivir in other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV.

This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the activities of symbionts in the animal kingdom. We show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by the host to its symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, is critical for the maintenance of the mutualism between the two organisms. This glycan is consumed by the symbiont only at night, when the animal is active, and is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic crypts, which enhances the production of bioluminescence. This glycan-driven regulation of the symbiont’s habitat may be a common mechanism for the control of the activities of symbionts in the animal kingdom.

It shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed, and that this change can have a positive impact on students’ behavior and well-being. It also shows that the quality of teacher–student relationships can be improved, and that this change can have a positive impact on students’ behavior and well-being. DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that the three regioisomeric EtdT lesions have distinct effects on the fidelity checkpoints and transcriptional lesion bypass routes. The results from the present in vitro transcriptional studies are well correlated with in vivo transcriptional mutagenesis analysis. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked the first cleavages. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that sequential proteolysis is a determinant of MERS-CoV tropism, and may be a target for therapeutic intervention.

This study provides evidence that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of vegetarian meals purchased. This has important implications for the environment and population health. The study also provides evidence that nudging meal selection can be effective in the real world, and that the effect is sustained over time. The study is also notable for its use of a large-scale, multisite, observational and experimental design, which provides robust evidence of the effectiveness of this intervention. The study also provides evidence that the effect is sustained over time. The study also provides evidence that the effect is sustained over time.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a breast cancer cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant contribution to the field of cancer biology and drug discovery.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast ballots by mail rather than in person. However, the effects of vote-by-mail have not been systematically studied. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or electoral outcomes. However, vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. We discuss the implications of our findings for the future of election administration in the United States.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the molecular basis of viral pathogenesis. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is unique in its ability to form large-scale assemblies. These assemblies may be important for immune evasion and pathogenesis, and may also be important for the rapid spread of the virus.

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a potential trigger of cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats, and that this is associated with an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that the increase in AQP4 expression is mediated by the corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF)/CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) pathway. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypoxia, and may lead to the development of new therapies for this condition. (Show more)

We live in an age of big data and complex statistical modeling. The challenge is to make the most of the data and the modeling tools, while avoiding the pitfalls of overconfidence. We describe a new way of thinking about the problem of “selective inference” that is relevant to all of these tools. We illustrate the approach with a simple example.

The development of vascular networks is a key step in the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is difficult, and the development of a method to generate vascular networks is a major challenge. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In addition, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This method can be used to generate vascular networks for the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

We report the discovery of a third class of ligand for the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). We show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized epidermal tissue that is responsible for the coloration of the zebrafish. We also show that these ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in the eye. These findings establish a physiological link between the ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that the ligands are required for the differentiation of neural crest-derived cells into iridophores. This work provides a new perspective on the role of ligand in the regulation of cell fate determination. (Show more)

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the influenza A virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates genomic packaging. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles. The interaction we identified involves regions not previously designated as packaging signals and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and might be useful for the development of new influenza vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Show more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are the result of a complex interplay between genetic and environmental factors. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61, connective tissue growth factor, and ankyrin repeat domain 1. In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. YAP/TAZ knockdown significantly attenuated the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. In addition, treatment with statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibited YAP/TAZ activities to diminish the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. Our results demonstrate a critical role of the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow in promoting atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. (Show more

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but they can also be a threat to human communities. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that people have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, and that this expansion has been driven by human activities. We discuss the implications of these findings for policy and management, and highlight the need for a better understanding of the role of people in driving fire regimes.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune system in the pathogenesis of the disease is well established. Here we present a mathematical model of the dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment and can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. The model can also be used to predict the effect of the immune system on the dynamics of the virus. This model can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials.

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on Earth, but they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. We demonstrate that the metabolic energy demand of the coral host increases during heat stress, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. This shift from uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a barrier to the environment and regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also a dynamic tissue that can be regulated by the microbiome. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome, which is critical for the maintenance of epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the development of therapies to treat intestinal cancers and dysbiotic microbiomes. They also provide insights into the regulation of intestinal homeostasis and the development of intestinal diseases.

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. We show that chemotherapy treatment of breast cancer cells enhances the expression of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1, which in turn enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to form cancer stem cells, which may be responsible for the relapse of some patients. We also show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with a humanized anti-ROR1 antibody, cirmtuzumab, and chemotherapy is more effective than treatment with chemotherapy alone in eradicating the tumors. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy in patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most important events in the past 100,000 y, but the cause is still debated. We show that a volcanic eruption series at the start of deglaciation is consistent with a strong impact on climate and the ozone layer.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human and economic stress. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, but that these populations are particularly reliant on inland fisheries compared with marine or aquaculture sources. Our results highlight the importance of rivers and lakes in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein, but also the need for improved management to ensure that fisheries do not undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system, but the molecular mechanisms that control it are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to be required for regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular control of regeneration in the adult nervous system, as well as the potential for therapeutic intervention.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key factor in the evolution of a species. However, the spatial pattern of recombination is not well understood. We use a population of wild monkeyflowers to map the location of recombination events in a flowering plant. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions that are completely devoid of recombination. These regions are interspersed with regions of intense recombination, which are more likely to occur near the start of genes than in the middle or end of genes. The spatial pattern of recombination is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice.

The resting brain is organized in topographically distinct networks, which are thought to reflect functional properties of the brain. However, the functional significance of these networks is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the brain is also topographically distinct, and that this organization is altered in disease. These results provide a new perspective on the organization of the brain, and may have implications for the understanding of brain function and dysfunction.

We report the discovery of a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). This cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs, and is not found on non-protein-coding transcripts. We propose that this cap structure is a form of RNA modification that could have important functional consequences.

The study of the epigenetic landscape of human blood cells has revealed that DNA methylation patterns are stable over time, and that these patterns are associated with the risk of developing diabetes complications. We show that these epigenetic patterns are also stable over time in people with diabetes, and that these patterns are associated with the risk of developing complications. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. They also provide a potential target for the development of new therapies to prevent or treat diabetes complications.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and the lack of estrogen and progesterone receptors and the absence of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) expression make it resistant to endocrine therapy and anti-HER2 therapy, respectively. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC and its mechanism of action are unknown. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, and that this alteration is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence, and this alteration is associated with the gut barrier. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence, and that it could be a target for the management of the disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, and the production of many of these compounds is not well understood. We report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation of a single precursor, 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid. This pathway is unique to tomato and likely contributes to the distinctive flavor of this species.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is a key target for understanding the neural basis of spatial cognition. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a novel approach to study the organization of MEC in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are critical for the formation of a topological map of the environment, are anatomically segregated from other cell types. These findings provide a foundation for future studies of the functional organization of MEC. They also have implications for the development of neurotechnology for navigation and spatial memory.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for flowering of the host and the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine system of the brain and body. It is caused by the loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the midbrain, the substantia nigra. We show that dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra are not isolated, but are part of a complex system that includes striosomes, a region of the striatum that is thought to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. We also show that dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra are part of a system that includes striosomes, the striatum, and the rest of the brain.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people “click”? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart and is responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are responsible for the generation of the electrical impulse that propagates through the heart and is the source of the heartbeat. SAN cells are specialized cardiomyocytes that are responsible for the generation of the heartbeat. SAN cells are also responsible for the generation of the heartbeat.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well established. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA act in concert to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest control. (Show more)

The lipidome of cells is a complex network of lipids, which are involved in many cellular processes. The lipidome of macrophages is of particular interest because of their important role in the immune system and in the pathogenesis of many diseases. Here we show that the activity of a specific enzyme in the ether lipid pathway is regulated by tetrahydrobiopterin, a cofactor essential for nitric oxide synthesis. We also show that the activity of this enzyme is important for the regulation of the lipidome of macrophages.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability that occur during the course of experience. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can bind information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are the most important source of food and medicine for the human race. However, the delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge. This work demonstrates that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and the results are applicable to other organisms as well.

The world’s largest freshwater lakes are vulnerable to coastal eutrophication, which can harm the health of the lake and the communities that depend on it. We show that small streams can be a major source of nutrients to the nearshore zone of large lakes, where they can fuel harmful algal blooms. Our findings have important implications for the management of nutrient inputs to lakes and other water bodies worldwide.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the dynamics of the network are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. We show that this bias is responsible for the emergence of a steady-state behavior in the network, even though the environment is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We discuss the implications of our results for the design of catalytic systems and for the study of the emergence of life.

This paper provides a detailed description of the results, the conclusions derived from these results, and an explanation of those conclusions. No additional experiments are described in this abstract.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in the field of Earth system history. However, the history of abrupt climate change is poorly understood because of the difficulty in identifying and quantifying these events. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event can be linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event can be explained by a change in the Earth system state, which led to an increase in nutrient fluxes and anoxia.

The palm oil industry is a major driver of tropical deforestation, and many countries and corporations have made commitments to reduce this impact. Certification is the main tool used to fulfill these commitments, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification body. We show that certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that the benefits are limited to areas that are already degraded and contain little residual forest. Certification has no causal impact on active fire detection rates or peatland deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is unlikely to meet its stated goals of reducing deforestation in the palm oil sector.

The exocytosis process is essential for the release of proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum to the plasma membrane and the recycling of the endocytic vesicles to the plasma membrane. The exocytosis process is tightly regulated, and the dysfunction of the exocytosis process is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered a small molecule that inhibits the exocytosis process in plants and humans. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental feature of the animal kingdom, and the evolution of sex determination alleles is a major driver of phenotypic variation. Here we show that the evolution of sex determination alleles can result in a modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, which can be used to understand the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct forms of oxidative stress. One is the photochemical oxidation of the pigment molecule, A2E, which leads to the formation of a large number of reactive intermediates. The other is the oxidation of the vitamin A aldehyde adducts, which are formed by photochemical oxidation of vitamin A and its derivatives. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are known to be important for redox reactions, impact the oxidation and degradation of A2E and bisretinoids. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding the structure and functioning of ecosystems. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it requires morphological changes throughout the entire organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a case of morphological diversification that has shaped the structure of food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. However, the origin of the distinctive human hand morphology is poorly understood because of the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand, was present ∼1.42 My old in a fossil from Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human behavior. (Less)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key metabolic pathway that supports cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), and used it to identify a metabolic vulnerability of cancer cells. We show that the one-carbon donor, formate, rescues SHMT inhibition in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. We also show that cancer cells have defective glycine import, and that this is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. Thus, we have identified a metabolic vulnerability of cancer, and a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer.

The importance of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized. This study shows that deforestation in rural Tanzania led to a reduction in people’s fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using a causal modeling approach to understand the effects of environmental change on people’s diets. This approach can be used to understand the effects of other environmental changes in the future.

The history of modern agriculture is the history of mechanization, with the increase in vehicle weight leading to the expansion of arable land. However, the weight of farm machinery has increased at a faster rate than the weight of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. We show that the weight of modern farm vehicles is now approaching that of the largest sauropods, and that the increase in weight has led to a chronic subsoil compaction risk, with potential loss of productivity. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the fact that the largest sauropods, the brachiosaurs, had a fixed foraging trail. Our results have important implications for the history of agriculture and for the evolution of animal behavior. They also suggest that the history of farming may be intertwined with the history of the environment.
